comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wexford Street crops up repeatedly in these Cleansing photos, and I wondered where exactly it was - roughly where Wentworth Avenue now is. The whole area was demolished in slum clearance schemes and rebuilt. 1895 interactive map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0... Maybe Exeter Place is the street running SE from the "E" of Wexford Street, judging by the shadows ?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Here's a view of Exeter Place looking the other way, from Foster Street - www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/history/sydneystreets/Lost_St... - so I think you are spot on, as the only other lane that runs between Wexford and Foster appears to simply be a narrowing of Campbell street.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] A Paradise of Laneways Lost - I think I can just make out Exeter, or is it Foster Place ? www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/history/sydneystreets/Lost_St...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Exeter Place earned a wonderfully Dickensian description of a visit in August 1870 (30 years before this photo the area was already infamous) - ' Among the alleys on the eastern side of the Haymarket, there is one, called Exeter-place, which may claim a dismal pre-eminence in wretchedness ...", and much more - SMH 13/8/1870 p.8 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13214875

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Wonderful stuff! The 'Sydney by Night' series started in The Rocks - No I. A VISIT TO THE ROCKS. SMH Friday 1/7/1870 p.5 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/28418893 No. 2. DONOVAN'S-LANE, THE PIGEON-HOUSE, AND COHEN'S-COUIRT. SMH Friday 8/7/1870 p.5 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13207919 No. 3. SIXPENNY LODGING-HOUSES. SMH Friday 15/7/1870 p.5 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13219484 No. 4. DRUITT-STREET AND WALLACE-LANE. SMH Monday 25/7/1870 p.5 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13220509 No. 5. ELIZABETH-STREET AND ITS VICINITY. SMH Saturday 30/7/1870 p.7 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13208774 No. 6. THE SOUP KITCHEN - A NICE QUARTER. SMH Saturday 6/8/1870 p.7 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13217738 No.7. EXETER PLACE [see comment above] which appears to be the last of the weekly installments. I wonder who the author was?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] What a great find!  The author seems to revel in all the squalor and wretchedness, and I bet Victorian newspaper readers loved hearing about other's misfortunes.  
Enough material there for a book?  With illustrations.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: No.16 Exeter Place boasted my favourite photo in the entire series. DON'T LOOK - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Great discussion beachcomber and pelle! And beachcomber - thanks for sharing your 'favourite' photo! I have to say, outhouses do feature prominently in the plague albums - often revoltingly close to food production areas or barefooted children! I'm quite partial to the sausages and adjacent toilets in this one: www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/5763262277/in/set... You're both right about the location of Exeter Place - it was one of several streets that disappeared in the Wexford St resumption of 1906. Now substantially covered by Wentworth Ave.
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection
